answers.answer: Hi there. Your grandchild could be having migraines, which are known to occur in the young also. It is possible that he is not able to address these due to anxiety and lack of knowledge. You need to look for and answer certain questions like does she have headaches, how long do the headaches last, how often does she get them, any triggers, the location of pain and the sensation, any associated symptoms like nausea, sensitivity to light etc. your family history of headaches need to be checked. Get his blood sugar profile done to check if he has diabetes. His fasting and post prandial blood glucose levels need  to be assessed. He could be having raised intracranial pressure due to an intracranial neoplasm or cyst. An MRI brain may be required. Show him to a pediatric neurologist for assessment. Hope this helps. Take care.

question: My four year old grandson has times when he says his head hurts and then pulls on his hair.  He likes to put a icepack on it and says it makes "the pain" feel better.  We suspect, but he has only seen his children dr. who gave my daughter a referal to a neuroligist but she didn't go, that he may have sensory issues...doesn't like loud noices, doesn't like large groups, does like a lot of touch though and he sees someone for his speech (and he is talking pretty good).  Could this head/hair pain be neurologal?  I am his caregiver and would like to give my daughter any help/information facing this and I want my grandson to get attention if he needs it.  Let me thank you in advance!
title: Scalp/hair pain
